lines.text: Someone's wife is pretty mad.
My goodness, she's angry. I feel sorry for the poor fellow. Whose teepee is it?
Mine.
What's wrong with Sully? You think he'd be happy to finally get to...
Hank, I think this discussion can hold.
It's all right, Reverend. Ma told us about the birds and the bees.
I doubt she told you Hank's version.
So why don't ya marry our Ma and be our Pa?
Brian!
Brian, it's not something you just do. It takes time.
She's 35. She doesn't have alot of time left!
Why did I come?
Yes.
I told ya.
What's the real reason?
Because.
Because...?
Because I love you.
I don't want ya to leave. I wanna be with you. I *need* to be with you.
Sully...
I will love you all my days. Will you marry me?
Yes.
I know what everyone is saying about me, that I'm an old maid. But I don't need you to contribute.
That's not what people are sayin'.
Yeah, no one's said nothin' about the maid part.
People who are popular when they're young... they often grow up to have very dull lives. And people who are different... they go on to be successful and make wonderful contributions.
Like who?
Well, like uh... like Abraham Lincoln!
Yeah, but they shot him!
What was I thinking? I had to be crazy! Any man puts up with your harpin's gotta be looney!
Any man who doesn't care about his friends isn't much of a man.
Don't worry Michaela, you're man enough for both of us.
Well, I never!
Yeah, well maybe that's the problem.

There's an old Indian legend that says man and woman were once united - four arms, four legs, two backs. And one day the great spirit grew angry at this creature and took his tomahawk and cut 'em apart. And ever since that day men and women have tried to get back together again.
Man and woman are not meant to be alone. Like Mother Earth and Father Sky, everyone needs a partner or they become unbalanced. It's nature.
Dr. Mike's an awfully strong force of nature.
Sully... In my heart I know where I want us to be. But I don't know how we'll get there.
Me neither... There's no maps, but if you're willing to start off without one...
I am.
Then I know where to start.
You're right. I was jealous.
I know.
It was foolish.
It was.
Must you agree with me *all* of the time?
Sully, tell Michaela if she needs her wick trimmed to let me know.
I'd be glad to, Hank, but the truth is, you're not man enough to hold a candle to her.

[about Michaela]
She's my heartsong.

Michaela, I love you. And I would do anything for you. I'd give my life for you, you know that. And I wanna marry you. But more than that, I want you to be happy. So you gotta choose the person who's gonna make you happy - the person that would be best for you. And whatever you do, I'll be behind you. I just wanted you to know that.
You love David.
Yes, I'll always love him. But that's the past and you're the present... *we're* the present... If you'll have me... Will you, Sully?

[pauses]
Will I what?
Will you marry me?
...Yes.
There's only one thing I know about women - you gotta be lucky enough to find the right one, and then never let her go.

[to Michaela]
I know what you're thinkin', and the answer's 'yes'. I'll always love you, no matter what happens. I'll always find you as beautiful as the first day I saw you.
You mean if I were Arapaho and you were Cheyenne...
We couldn't get married, nope.
[pauses]
I'd have to carry you off in the night.
I could use some advice... from someone who's had experience.
Oh. Well, don't you worry. It's as easy as falling off a log.
Remember, I've never... fallen off a log.
We're the same two people we were before we got married. Nothin's changed.
But it has. Everything's changed. It's no longer 'you' and 'me', it's 'us'. You're a part of me now. And that's a very powerful feeling.
Horace, you're the behind.
Behind what?
The striker.
I'm the striker's behind?
You know what the Cheyanne ask a young man who's just taken a wife?
What?
'Does she show enthusiasm?'... I appreciate your enthusiasm.
After Dr. Mike has the baby... are you gonna let 'er keep workin'?
[laughs]
What's so funny?
Let her? Are we talkin' about the same Dr. Mike?
I see your point.

[to Sully]
If a lady like Dr. Quinn looked at me the way she looks at you, I'd fall down on one knee and promise myself to her forever.
Do you think a man can love two women at the same time?
If you were one of the women, would you want him to?

[to Dr. Mike]
You toss apple peelin's over your shoulder and they spell out the initials of who you're going to marry.
You oughtta try it, Dr. Mike.
Bet it'd be a big 'S'!

[embarrassed]
Brian!

[to Michaela]
This is the place I come when I lose my way and I have to find it again. I've never shown anyone this place... Not even Abigail.

[to Michaela about Sully]
Even if I wasn't your friend, that man has no place in his heart for anyone but you. He's like a needle on a compass that points true north. Don't you know that?... He's as straight and sure as you are. That's the one way that you're alike, and it's more important than all the little ways that you're different.
I'm good at fixin' things when I can see what's wrong. But, this thing that's comin', it's so big... I don't know where to start.
We'll find a way. But I promise you, if the day ever comes that I see your heart breaking and you can't take it any longer, we'll pack up.
You have always been a foolish man. I do not know why I have slept with you for so long.
I am fond of you, also.

[pointing to Michaela after an ouburst by Marjorie]
And I thought this one was bad!
I'll be your family.
And I'll be your best friend.
Is it just me, or have I been pregnant for ten years?
It'll be over soon.
And you've been saying that to me for ten years as well.
I'll still can't believe I have a baby sister.
Well, she's got your eyes, Sully.
Not much hair, though... considerin' its parents.
I'm running away.
From what?
Ma said it's somethin' called puberty. I don't wanna catch it.
No drinky. Bad water. You get 'em?
She's awfully angry.
You have stuck your hand in a hornet's nest that was hidden. I have done that myself.
Well, if this is what it's gonna be like bein' with a woman, I don't know if I'm fit for it.
Black Kettle and his party are late for his treaty council.
The Cheyenne say that only a white man needs a watch to tell him when he's hungry.
What's all the racket? I can hardly hear myself think.
Hard enough for you to think as it is!
Do you love 'im?

How *dare* you ask me that! You, who have told me that you're not ready to love anyone! You, who comes and goes as he pleases! You, who never so much as offered any kind of committment to me and my children!
Do. You. *Love* 'im?
I'm very fond of the Reverend. And he's made me a proposal that no one, including you, has cared to do. And I don't take that lightly.
If marriage is all you want, then you've found the right man.
You know what Sam said? She said that seeing us together is like watching a fire burn.
Is that good?
Well, ignore a fire and it burns out. But if you tend to it, take care of it, feed it... it keeps growing bigger - burns brighter.
I can't say if your spirits exist or not. I'm not even sure how I feel about my own God anymore.
Just because we are angry with them does not mean they will go away.
I like talking... and I like having breakfast with you. But I also like *kissin'*.
Well, there should be a balance.
But you're good at kissin'.
Sully!
Speakin' of ladies... May I?
No, you may not.
Pleased to almost meet you.
Sully... it isn't dark yet.

[pulling the shades]
But it's getting darker... and darker... and darker.

[pulling the last shade]
... and darker.
Newlyweds! Well that explains everything. I was wondering why they were the only two on the train *not* enjoying the view.
The marriage is good?
Yeah. It's great.
It took Snow Bird and I many months to discover that we no longer rode separate horses.
You never told me you played baseball.
Just for fun. We used to play it in the mining camps.
This rule book is very interesting. I never realized it was such an orderly and courteous game.
Not the way *we* played it.
Where does that leave Horace? He's been struggling at the plate. He's afraid of striking out.
He's not the only one...
You're looking very pleased with yourself.
When the children knock and you don't jump up, I know I got your attention.
Do you think most women find it agreeable?
Sure.
If they're in love, they do.
I think women find it more agreeable then men do. I *do*. I mean, the men don't wanna know it. It would just vex 'em.
You're still in the honeymoon stage. Enjoy it. 'Cause it ain't gonna last forever.
I don't think so. I mean, I don't think it has to end.
No, but it just gets different, that's all. Sorta gets to be a part of the day's routine, like... brushing your teeth.

[kissing Sully]
How can people say this is like brushing your teeth?

[discussing Colleen]
We were always so close.
Maybe that's the problem.
Beg your pardon?
She's gotta step outta your shadow. It's a mighty tall shadow.
Do I look as foolish as I feel?
I think you're beautiful when you're jealous.
What's a dog like that good for?
Bait.
D'you hear the news? Dr. Mike is climbing to the top of Pike's Peak.
Don't worry. After a while, nothin' she does'll seem strange.
I'll only be five minutes.
No, no. I know how long five minutes takes when someone leaves a baby with you.
Colleen, can I ask you somethin'?
Sure.
Say you're a girl...
I'll try to imagine that.

Whenever anyone used to comment on my being my father's daughter, he used to tell them not to let my choice of profession fool them. That it was my mother I was most like, not him. It's the only thing he ever said that made me truly angry at him.
She kissed *me*.
What's the difference?
It takes two people to kiss, Brian. It's like when you wanna go fishin' and I don't, but I go anyway because I don't wanna hurt your feelings. Do you think you can understand that?
I think fishin's fishin' and kissin's kissin'. That's what I think.
I'm not a little girl anymore. I don't need you.
Colleen, you always need your father.
Father? Sully is my father!
How long before we go?
You're not going. The women stay in camp.
Not this woman.
I ain't stupid.
Well, that's a matter of opinion.
What's it like to walk on water, Michaela?

Dr. Quinn, I do not want the war to be all that I remember when I close my eyes forever. I want to take every photograph I can. I want to fill my memory with wonder and beauty. I want to recall every sunrise and every mountain peak that reaches for the heavens. And I want to remember women... who look just the way you do right now. May I take your portrait? Please?
This is the best chance he has!
No, *I'm* the best chance!
That's your opinion. But he's my patient and I'll decide what's best for him.
Dr. Cassidy, if my name was Michael Quinn and not Michaela, you'd let me perform that procedure wouldn't you?
I don't give a damn what your name is. I know Drew. And I know he would much rather take his chances on a wagon trip to Denver than have a hysterical female cut him open!

[after Drew is brought back, having died on the route to Denver]
What do you think his chances are now, doctor?
Don't we have enough?
You wanna learn to fish... ya gotta dig for worms.
Ha! Here's one.
Half worms don't count.
Why not?
It's fishin' rules.
We'll take that horse also.
What? How am I s'posed to get back?
You can keep the shoes.
We can't have a lady mayor! What's that gonna make us look like?
A town full of sissies?
Of course they're true! That's how they get to be rumors!
I think Dr. Mike's in trouble.
What kinda trouble?
What kinda trouble does she usually get into?
What's that squallin'?
Somebody's singin'. Sounds like Myra.
Myra can't sing!
Well, that ain't stoppin' her. Listen!
Who the hell is Ralph Waldo?
Probably another darn woman from Boston.
Great, now we've got two of 'em.
[rehearsing Tybalt for the local production of Romeo and Juliet]
Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries that thou hast done me. Therefore, turn and draw! And I'll hack off your head before you can count to three.
Wait a minute. Stop. Stop. 'Hack off your head' is not in the play.
I fixed that line a little.
You can't just change the lines, Hank.
I think it's better. Not only that, it rhymes.

[sighs]
Actors!
You can't close your heart and give up on people. When you shut down the door, no one can get in.
Why don't ya just drop me down the side of the mountain and have done with it.
Don't tempt me.
You're gettin' one helluva woman!
Good luck, Sully.
You're gonna need it.

[to Sully]
Let's just elope. I don't care about any fancy wedding. All I care about is being your wife... and you being my husband... I'm ready to start looking at the world through *our* eyes.
That woman was a doctor? Well, I can hardly wait to get sick!
Who's up next?
Me.
You can't play, you're a girl.
Then you should have no trouble striking me out.

When I first thought that David had been killed, I felt as if my heart had been ripped out. I didn't believe that anything could ever hurt me as much again. Seeing my child go through it... It's worse.
Blamin' doesn't fix things. It just makes them go on and on tearin' at folks.
Dorothy's overcome so much herself. I think she means this book to be inspirational. I'm sure she didn't mean to offend anyone.
You read it?
I haven't had time yet. I'm looking forward to reading it this afternoon.
Where exactly you gonna be when you're readin' it?
The clinic, I suppose. Why?
Might wanna steer clear of that part of town today, folks.
Keeping promises when it's convenient is easy Michaela. But easy don't count for much in life.

[to Michaela]
Whether or not we make a baby, we sure can have fun trying.
I started thinking about how I planned everything. Then I realized something. The most important events in my life were things that I never planned. Things that I had no control over at all.
Oh, no you don't.
I was just sayin' hello.
I know you, and you were one step away from namin' that turkey.
Well, his face does kinda remind me of...
Shhh. Don't say it. You name that bird, start makin' friends with it, and there goes my Thanksgiving appetite. That bird's name is 'dinner'.

[to Jake]
With the Cheyanne, tribe comes first, then family and then man. For you, it's the man first and last. That is why you are so alone.
Got somthin' for ya... an early Christmas present.
Really?

[producing a beaded leather necklace]
I made this when I was with the Cheyanne. Didn't make it for myself, but to give as a gift. And all these years I been walkin' around with it, not knowin' who I made it for until now. I made it for my son.
What's myrrh?
Well, myrrh was a... It is a... It's a thing that kings have.
[after Dr. Mike is accepted into a prestigious medical society]
And we thought she was know-it-all before this.
Bein' sheriff's a man's job, Grace.
I know. That's why I'm votin' for Matthew.

[to Matthew]
You're considerably younger than Hank.
He's also considerably smarter.
Thanks for the support, Myra.
You'll have to excuse Sully. He has a tender spot in his heart for squirrels and bunnies and such.
What do you say, Sully? Do you think I should keep my mouth shut?
I don't think it's possible, Preston.

I am reminded of a story. It seems a young frog was trying to win the heart of a porcupine. His father said to him, "My son, how can you fall in love with a porcupine?" The young frog replied, "The skunk would not have me."
[blank look]
I'm afraid it loses something in the translation.
It's your funeral, Reverend.
Yes, it is. And I would like to wait on it.
Why'd you do it? Why'd you save my life?
If you don't know by now, you never will.
You did the right thing, Hank.
Don't let it get around.
What was it this time?
She thought she saw a bear out the window.
A bear?
It was a laundry tub. Took quite a fight, but I think I scared it off.
I always thought she was disappointed in me... when I left Boston to move out here... as if I'd somehow failed.
She was disappointed, or you?

[looks lovingly at Sully]
It was the best decision I ever made.

[smiling]
Glad to hear you say that.
There're some mornings, I just want to stay in bed and hide under the covers. Or take a buggy ride out to the lake... not let anyone know where I am... Just let life go on without "Dr. Mike".
It would, ya know.
Carpe diem.
Carpet what?

[to Sully]
It's been a while since we've had an adventure in the woods.
Oh, Sully, I don't wanna do this. I don't think I can.
Yes you can. You're doin' it right now. Pretty soon the baby'll be here... and your ten years of being pregnant are over.
May I ask you a question?
Yeah.
Why don't you have clothes on?
Well, I'm seventy-three years old. And I figure I can do as I damn well please.
Tobacco? You know what that'll do for your tuberculosis?
No ma'am, but I'm sure you're plannin' on tellin' me.
Rich people pay to eat snails?
Pushy? I'm not pushy!
Let's just call it headstrong.

[about Dr. Mike]
She was aiding the enemy.
Ah, she thought she was helping the Indians. She just does stuff like that. Ya gotta ignore it.
High stakes poker, Michaela. Bunch of stinkin' drunk men sittin' around a table gamblin', smokin', talkin' dirty and we'd like for you to come. Interested?
No, thank you.
Darn.
There's a sayin' - 'The devel you know is better then the devil you don't know'. Well, Hank, you're the devil we know.

[to Michaela]
Sometimes a shadow falls over the moon, and it looks dark. But the light's there, it's just behind it. It's not gone, it's just covered up for a while. You've got that light. I've seen it. Trust that it's there and the shadow will pass.
Hey, you think we outta tell Dr. Mike about our plan?
Naw. What she don't know won't hurt us.
I've never thought of caution as a means to lead one's life.
I had a lady doctor take out my lumbago in St. Louis.
Took it right out, did she?
I think we've had this discussion before Reverend. Do you or do you not answer to a higher power?
Maybe you better figure that out, Reverend.
Do whatever you want to do with my mortgage. I'll practice in the street if I have to. I'll pitch a tent, I'll work from my wagon, but I will never, *never* give in to the likes of you!

[to Jedediah Bancroft]
And I have a few words for you but propriety prevents me from saying them.
They stole my purse!
Well, I'm sorry that you were robbed, but I must say you're looking rather lovely this evening.
What will Cloud Dancing do without me?
Horace, are you all right?
How many fingers?
Chocolate.
I think he's finished for the day.
What took you so long?
I had to make my bat.
Pinch running for Mr. Slicker will be Cloud Dancing.
Ingrid, will you marry me? Right now. We can do it here. God can be our witness.
Why can't you accept me for what I am?

And what are you? You're an unmarried woman, trying to raise three children, in a shack, in the middle of nowhere... and offering your medical services to a bunch of back-woodsman, who pay you in potatoes and in chickens.
Why don't ya quit tryin' so hard?
Old habits.
Give 'em up.
Don't be stubborn.
It's an old habit.
Give it up.
I think it's time to set aside our differences.
Not by my watch.
Whiskey and truth should both be served straight up, Doctor.
You're not a bad doctor.
And you're not a bad general.

That's what I wanted more than anything when I was workin' for Hank - a nice normal life. When Horace and I first fell in love, I was so happy. We'd get married in a nice normal church weddin', and live in a normal house, and have a normal family.
[pauses]
Normal life is drivin' me crazy.
Well, it's gotta be better than workin' in a saloon.
Yeah. But I used to speak my mind. I had gumption.

[talking about Ingrid]
She told Jon that she always wanted to remember this music.
[he breaks down crying]
And that way'd she'd never forget what it felt like to fall in love with me.
[Loren, Hank and Jake are dressed up to play the Three Wise Men for the Christmas nativity]
Reverend. How do we look?
I don't think they were smoking cigars, gentlemen.
Hey, we're kings. We can do whatever we want.
The minute you put on a gun, you're sayin' that you're willin' to use it. Now, that's just invitin' trouble.

[to Matthew]
I don't ever want to see you lying here, looking up at me and telling me you got shot for the right reasons. There are no right reasons to get shot.
You don't raise children to keep 'em in way that puts your mind at ease. You raise 'em so they know how to look out for themselves.
Different women give you different kinds of love.
How do you even know if it *is* love?
Let your heart tell ya. Just make sure it's your heart doin' the talkin'.
You could sell the extra corn just to buy things you need - like some meat.
*Buy* meat?

Interesting character. Remind you of anyone you know? Mountain man turned family man? Once a legend of the rugged back country, now cooking supper for his pregnant wife. Don't take me wrong, Sully. I want nothing but the best for you and Michaela. I can picture you right now with a new baby - rocking him to sleep, changing his little buckskin diapers.
Care to show us some of them moves?
With you?
Why not? Been a while since I mixed it up a bit.
Yeah, at least a week.
Dr. Cassidy, it's quite apparent that my definition of a woman will always differ from yours. So let's just agree to disagree and leave it at that, shall we?
I'd feel a lot better if I had a deputy, just 'till this is all over. I don't trust many men. I'd ask Sully but I need someone here in town.
I'm sorry, Matthew. I can't help you. I ain't sayin' that man in there don't have due what's comin' 'im. Just figure I already seen my fill of hangin's.
Look at you. You ain't hardly wet behind the ears. And they think that you can do a man's job today.
Watch me, Reed.
Come to save my soul?
I suppose that's up to you.
When you read a story, you cannot know who tells it - cannot see him, or hear his voice. If you cannot see his spirit, the story has no meaning.
Well, all we wanna do is give them a new way of learning, so they can have both ways.
Just so the new ways don't wipe out the old.
What of their true nature will survive if they live as white people?
All we want to do is prepare them for the future.
They won't have a future if they don't have a past.
What did I do wrong, Dr. Mike? I only wanted to do the right thing.
I know. They never asked us to share their religion, Reverend. Should we make them share ours?
They don't share our medicine, either, but you help them with it.
Medicine is different...
How? You took an oath to save lives with your medicine and I took an oath to save souls with my faith.

[gently]
I thought our job here was to educate their minds.
You visitin' town?
Well, I was passing through on the train and I saw this...
[gestures toward the mountains]
... and I just had to get out and paint it.
You mean, you see something you wanna paint... and you stop everything to do it?
Yes.
I find the canvases of Mr. Monet and Pissaro very exciting, mind you. But, I must say, they can't hold a candle to yours.
Oh, my. What a warm breeze there is out here.
I need your help. I still can't get this 'perspective' thing right.
You have better perspective than most people I know.

Isabelle, I'd like for you to stay. I wish I could just make my fear go away... or that I never felt it in the first place, but I can't... But my fear is irrelevent. You're sick and I can help. That's all that matters... Please? I want to be your doctor.
There is no justice in the white man's court.

At Washita, I watched my life drain away with the blood of my people... Snowbird... Black Kettle. I came to the reservation where Utes fight Pawnee, Pawnee fight Arapaho. But now, the spirits have shown me a way to bring peace. They have shown me we are one blood... one people.
Cloud Dancing, this is admirable, but you can't sacrifice yourself.
You asked me before if I was protecting someone. I am protecting them all.

[reguarding Emma]
I will not have a woman of such character in attendance.
A woman of such character, mother, is mearly the direct result of the *men* who exploit her.
Please don't start that again.
Men who share none of the shame and degredation, who insist on enslaving us...
All right, all right! Invite her! Just cease with the fanatacism!
How did he get the hernia?
Lifting a pig... a *big* pig.

[to baby Sully]
Your pa made this just for you... *our* pa.
What happened?
Some guy cut me. How much to sew me up?
I thought you prefered the expertise of Mr. Slicker in these matters.
Jake's drunk. Now can we talk later, when I'm not bleedin' to death?
Sometimes people disappoint you, and you just have to let it go and love them anyway.
Seems parents and children spend half their lives not seeing eye to eye. By the time they do find some common ground, there's barely any time left to enjoy it.
Sheriff. Must be of strong moral fiber and have knowledge of the law.
There go most of your candidates right there.
Looks like the only way I'm gonna have me a quiet, peaceful little town is to make me one.

[to Mike]
You ain't gonna be my boss, are ya?
I know I'm new in town, but it woulda been nice to've been invited to your party.
The Cheyanne say that the dead carry their scars with them to the afterlife.
Well, I disagree. I believe it's the people who are left who carry the scars.
Remember, the two-leggeds and the four-leggeds were made by the same creator. We are relatives.
You're drunk.
That's an excellent diagnosis doctor.
Dr. Quinn, you are a traitor.
I've dedicated my life to repairing the damage that men like you bring on this world and frankly, Mr. Custer, I don't want any more of your business.
That's the gate to wisdom - being able to say 'I don't know'.
My life is very ordinary.
After my years of photographing the war I think an ordinary life is amazing. Especially if it's viewed from the proper angle.
I'm sorry for everything my people are doin' to yours.
The spirits tell me my anger is good, my hate is not. There are good men, there are bad men. You're a good man Sully. You're still my brother.
What can I do for ya?
Well, you can come home to the Lord, brother. He's missing you.
Sorry, I can't say the same.
You let a dang woman work on me? What're you tryin' to kill me?
This ain't no woman. She's a doctor.
What happened to your plans to settle down, plant some rose bushes?
Boys like him kept tryin' to make me push up rose bushes instead of plantin' 'em.
I stand with the truth.
Black Kettle says that is the only place for a leader to stand.
Where you're born always kind of has a pull on ya, whether ya like it or not.
Please, mother needs her rest!
Oh, nonsense. I feel perfectly well.
Doctor's orders.
A nap. But then I'm coming down for supper.
Mother...
And *that* is final.
Mother's orders.
Sully says that everyone recognizes members of their own tribe.
Who's Sully?
Well, that's something for a whole other picnic.
'all her puppies don't bark'.
Life isn't about living forever, Michaela. It's about making the journey really count.
Sometimes I think you must really hate me, mother.
I thought Matthew was taking you fishing?
He's too busy... kissin' Ingrid.
We got ourselves a sheriff - Matthew Cooper.
I want a recount.
I know how to count, Hank. You lost by more than thirty votes.
You still racing horses?
Of course. And are you still dressing up as men to ride them?
How does cutting their hair and putting them in white man's clothes help them learn?
Michaela Quinn of Beacon Hill, out in the barren wilderness, scratching the ears of a wolf.
As you said, things change.
I've been through this before. Fear and guilt aren't the best treatments for me.
Michaela, I hope you don't mind... I brought along a friend for dinner.
Turkey. My favorite.

[to Mike]
There was no greater moment in my life, then the moment when I gave birth to you.

[to Preston]
You will wait you turn, young man, and be pleasant doing so!
Morning, folks. Like you to meet Katherine Sully.
We often see things clearer once we're looking backwards.

[about Michaela to Sully]
She shouldn't have to defend your appearance. You and I both know that you look nearly as odd to most of the people of Colorado Springs as you do to the citizens of Boston.
I don't want to belong to a church where you let a man lay dyin' while you sit here readin' your bibles.
Wait a minute, don't go. You're always runnin' off somewhere.Please, Stay.
If I stay, I might be tempted to do more than talk.
Kid! Let him go, let it all be over. Then maybe you and I could...
I just wish you'd get on outta here before you get hurt.
I'd *be* hurt if you die. I love you, you ole coot!
